items.title: Charlie Kirk's body flown on Air Force Two to Arizona
items.standfirst: Charlie Kirk was shot and killed at an event at Utah Valley University Wednesday. His body was flown on Air Force Two to Arizona, where he lived with his family.
items.content: Charlie Kirk was shot and killed at an event at Utah Valley University Wednesday. His body was flown on Air Force Two to Arizona, where he lived with his family.

items.title: Utah officials share video of Charlie Kirk shooting suspect as governor pledges death penalty - live
items.standfirst: Briefing follows release of four new images of suspect and reward offer of $100,000Hunt continues for suspect who fatally shot Charlie KirkHow the shooting unfolded – in maps, videos and imagesA UK offshoot of a US conservative group set up by Charlie Kirk is to hold a vigil in London after he was shot dead, reports the PA news agency.Turning Point UK has said its activists will gather on Friday evening by the Montgomery statue in Whitehall and called on others to “join us in remembering Charlie”.It’s absolutely shocking, we’re heartbroken over here in the UK.My thoughts this evening are with the loved ones of Charlie Kirk.It is heartbreaking that a young family has been robbed of a father and a husband.Political violence has no place in our societies.Our thoughts and condolences are with his family.An atrocious murder, a deep wound for democracy and for those who believe in freedom.My condolences to his family, to his loved ones, and to the American conservative community. Continue reading...
items.content: Briefing follows release of four new images of suspect and reward offer of $100,000Hunt continues for suspect who fatally shot Charlie KirkHow the shooting unfolded – in maps, videos and imagesA UK offshoot of a US conservative group set up by Charlie Kirk is to hold a vigil in London after he was shot dead, reports the PA news agency.Turning Point UK has said its activists will gather on Friday evening by the Montgomery statue in Whitehall and called on others to “join us in remembering Charlie”.It’s absolutely shocking, we’re heartbroken over here in the UK.My thoughts this evening are with the loved ones of Charlie Kirk.It is heartbreaking that a young family has been robbed of a father and a husband.Political violence has no place in our societies.Our thoughts and condolences are with his family.An atrocious murder, a deep wound for democracy and for those who believe in freedom.My condolences to his family, to his loved ones, and to the American conservative community. Continue reading...

items.content: Conservative activist and Turning Point USA co-founder Charlie Kirk died Wednesday after he was shot at an event at Utah Valley University.

items.title: Search for Charlie Kirk's killer continues. Here's what we know.
items.standfirst: Conservative activist Charlie Kirk was shot and killed on Wednesday while speaking an event at Utah Valley University. Authorities have not identified a suspect.
items.content: Conservative activist Charlie Kirk was shot and killed on Wednesday while speaking an event at Utah Valley University. Authorities have not identified a suspect.

items.title: Charlie Kirk’s body flown back to Arizona as search for suspect continues
items.standfirst: Vice-president JD Vance flies with casket as officials say rifle found and images of suspect releasedCharlie Kirk shooting: latest updatesHow the Charlie Kirk shooting unfolded – in maps, videos and imagesJD Vance, the vice-president, flew with the casket of the rightwing activist Charlie Kirk from Utah, where he was fatally shot, to Arizona, where the 31-year-old lived and grew his conservative youth movement, as the search for his killer continued.Kirk, a close political ally of Donald Trump and a personal friend of Vance, was shot on Wednesday afternoon during an open-air discussion attended by about 3,000 people at Utah Valley University (UVU) in Orem. The shooting, which the president called a “dark moment for America”, comes as the country grapples with mounting political anger and polarization. Continue reading...
items.content: Vice-president JD Vance flies with casket as officials say rifle found and images of suspect releasedCharlie Kirk shooting: latest updatesHow the Charlie Kirk shooting unfolded – in maps, videos and imagesJD Vance, the vice-president, flew with the casket of the rightwing activist Charlie Kirk from Utah, where he was fatally shot, to Arizona, where the 31-year-old lived and grew his conservative youth movement, as the search for his killer continued.Kirk, a close political ally of Donald Trump and a personal friend of Vance, was shot on Wednesday afternoon during an open-air discussion attended by about 3,000 people at Utah Valley University (UVU) in Orem. The shooting, which the president called a “dark moment for America”, comes as the country grapples with mounting political anger and polarization. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump urges peace after Charlie Kirk killing as manhunt continues
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump on Thursday urged supporters to remain peaceful after right-wing activist Charlie Kirk was shot dead, as police hunted the suspect more than a day later. Trump, who initially vowed a forceful response against the “radical left,” called Kirk an “advocate of nonviolence.
items.content: US President Donald Trump on Thursday urged supporters to remain peaceful after right-wing activist Charlie Kirk was shot dead, as police hunted the suspect more than a day later. Trump, who initially vowed a forceful response against the “radical left,” called Kirk an “advocate of nonviolence.

items.title: Assessing the Extent of Political Violence in America
items.standfirst: NA The awful murder of conservative activist Charlie Kirk has stimulated interest in the nature and extent of political violence in the United States. We do not yet know the identity and motive of the killer; but there is at least a substantial likelihood the motive was political in nature. My…

items.title: FBI seeks public's help to find person of interest in Charlie Kirk's assassination
items.standfirst: The FBI is seeking the public help's to find a man described as a person of interest in the assassination of conservative activist Charlie Kirk. Meanwhile, a reward of up to $100,000 is being offered for information leading to the identification and arrest of the killer. Carter Evans and Scott MacFarlane have more on the investigation, and Weijia Jiang reports on the reaction from the White House.
items.content: The FBI is seeking the public help's to find a man described as a person of interest in the assassination of conservative activist Charlie Kirk. Meanwhile, a reward of up to $100,000 is being offered for information leading to the identification and arrest of the killer. Carter Evans and Scott MacFarlane have more on the investigation, and Weijia Jiang reports on the reaction from the White House.

ai_summary: Conservative activist Charlie Kirk was shot and killed at Utah Valley University on Wednesday.
Authorities are actively searching for the suspect involved in the shooting incident.
The FBI released new images of a person of interest related to the shooting.
A UK group is holding a vigil to remember Charlie Kirk after the shooting.
The governor of Utah pledged to pursue the death penalty for the suspect.

items.content: Far-right populist found guilty of leading conspiracy that attempted to overthrow country’s democracy

items.title: Bolsonaro sentenced to 27 years for plotting military coup in Brazil
items.standfirst: Former president sought to ‘annihilate’ country’s democracy after losing 2022 electionExplainer: what did Bolsonaro’s trial reveal?​Brazil’s former far-right president Jair Bolsonaro ​has been sentenced to more than 27 years in prison for plotting a military coup​ and seeking to “annihilate” the South American country’s democracy.Justices Cármen Lúcia Antunes Rocha and Cristiano Zanin ruled on ​Thursday that Bolsonaro – a former paratrooper who was elected president in 2018 – was guilty of seeking to forcibly cling to power after losing the 2022 election, meaning four of the five judges involved in the trial had found Brazil’s former leader guilty. Continue reading...
items.content: Former president sought to ‘annihilate’ country’s democracy after losing 2022 electionExplainer: what did Bolsonaro’s trial reveal?​Brazil’s former far-right president Jair Bolsonaro ​has been sentenced to more than 27 years in prison for plotting a military coup​ and seeking to “annihilate” the South American country’s democracy.Justices Cármen Lúcia Antunes Rocha and Cristiano Zanin ruled on ​Thursday that Bolsonaro – a former paratrooper who was elected president in 2018 – was guilty of seeking to forcibly cling to power after losing the 2022 election, meaning four of the five judges involved in the trial had found Brazil’s former leader guilty. Continue reading...

items.title: Brazil Supreme Court sentences Bolsonaro to 27 years over coup plot
items.standfirst: Sentence comes shortly after a majority of justices voted to convict the former Brazilian leader on five charges.
items.content: Sentence comes shortly after a majority of justices voted to convict the former Brazilian leader on five charges.

items.title: Majority on Brazil's Supreme Court votes to convict Bolsonaro in coup trial
items.standfirst: Brazil's Supreme Court on Thursday reached the majority of three votes needed to convict firebrand ex-president Jair Bolsonaro of plotting a coup, making a lengthy prison sentence a near certainty. FRANCE 24's Tim Vickery reports from Rio de Janeiro.
items.content: Brazil's Supreme Court on Thursday reached the majority of three votes needed to convict firebrand ex-president Jair Bolsonaro of plotting a coup, making a lengthy prison sentence a near certainty. FRANCE 24's Tim Vickery reports from Rio de Janeiro.

items.title: Brazil's Supreme Court votes to convict ex-President Bolsonaro of a coup plot
items.standfirst: A historic conviction: Brazil's Supreme Court delivers a majority vote to convict former President Jair Bolsonaro over a plot to overthrow the government.
items.content: A historic conviction: Brazil's Supreme Court delivers a majority vote to convict former President Jair Bolsonaro over a plot to overthrow the government.(Image credit: Mateus Bonomi)

items.title: Former Brazil president Bolsonaro sentenced to more than 27 years for coup plot
items.standfirst: A majority of judges in Brazil's Supreme Court on Thursday found former president Jair Bolsonaro guilty of potting a coup to remain in office despite his 2022 electoral defeat. He was sentenced to more than 27 years in prison.
items.content: A majority of judges in Brazil's Supreme Court on Thursday found former president Jair Bolsonaro guilty of potting a coup to remain in office despite his 2022 electoral defeat. He was sentenced to more than 27 years in prison.

items.title: Brazil's Bolsonaro guilty of coup charges, court majority decides in landmark trial
items.standfirst: Former Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro was convicted by a Supreme Court majority on Thursday of plotting a coup to remain in power after losing the 2022 election, a powerful blow to the populist far-right movement he created. The presumptive ruling by a majority of a panel of five justices in Brazil's Supreme Court makes Bolsonaro the first former president in the country's history to be convicted for attacking democracy. FRANCE 24's Time Vickery reports from Rio De Janeiro.
items.content: Former Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro was convicted by a Supreme Court majority on Thursday of plotting a coup to remain in power after losing the 2022 election, a powerful blow to the populist far-right movement he created. The presumptive ruling by a majority of a panel of five justices in Brazil's Supreme Court makes Bolsonaro the first former president in the country's history to be convicted for attacking democracy. FRANCE 24's Time Vickery reports from Rio De Janeiro.

items.title: What did Jair Bolsonaro’s trial reveal about an attempted coup in Brazil?
items.standfirst: Far-right ex-president was found to have led a ‘criminal organisation’ to try to stay in powerBolsonaro found guilty of plotting military coupBrazil’s supreme court has made Jair Bolsonaro the first former president in the country’s history to be convicted for attempting a coup.The 70-year-old far-right leader claims he is the victim of political persecution, but three out of five judges concluded on Thursday that it was sufficiently proven that Bolsonaro and his close allies attempted to overturn the 2022 election, which he lost to Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva. Continue reading...
items.content: Far-right ex-president was found to have led a ‘criminal organisation’ to try to stay in powerBolsonaro found guilty of plotting military coupBrazil’s supreme court has made Jair Bolsonaro the first former president in the country’s history to be convicted for attempting a coup.The 70-year-old far-right leader claims he is the victim of political persecution, but three out of five judges concluded on Thursday that it was sufficiently proven that Bolsonaro and his close allies attempted to overturn the 2022 election, which he lost to Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva. Continue reading...

items.title: Updates: Brazil Supreme Court votes to convict Bolsonaro on all charges
items.standfirst: Bolsonaro set to be sentenced on charges related to planning coup after three justices vote to convict.
items.content: Bolsonaro set to be sentenced on charges related to planning coup after three justices vote to convict.

items.title: Brazil's ex-president jailed for 27 years for coup attempt - as Trump says conviction is 'very bad' for country
items.standfirst: Brazil's former president Jair Bolsonaro has been sentenced to 27 years and three months in prison for attempting a coup to stay in power after his 2022 election defeat.
items.content: Brazil's former president Jair Bolsonaro has been sentenced to 27 years and three months in prison for attempting a coup to stay in power after his 2022 election defeat.

ai_summary: Former Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro was convicted of plotting a military coup.
The Brazilian Supreme Court sentenced Bolsonaro to more than 27 years in prison.
Bolsonaro was found guilty of attempting to overturn the 2022 election results.
The court's ruling found Bolsonaro sought to cling to power after losing the election.
The conviction was based on five counts related to the coup attempt.

clusters.title: Israel has ‘gone beyond any borders’ with Doha strike, Qatar PM warns UN
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel and Qatar Tensions Rise Over Doha Strike

items.title: Israel has ‘gone beyond any borders’ with Doha strike, Qatar PM warns UN
items.standfirst: Israel’s leaders “do not care” about hostages in Gaza after striking Hamas officials in Doha this week, Qatar’s prime minister told the UN on Thursday. Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani said Israel had “gone beyond any borders” as world powers condemned Tuesday’s deadly attack on the US ally.
items.content: Israel’s leaders “do not care” about hostages in Gaza after striking Hamas officials in Doha this week, Qatar’s prime minister told the UN on Thursday. Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani said Israel had “gone beyond any borders” as world powers condemned Tuesday’s deadly attack on the US ally.

items.title: Trump to meet Qatar's PM Friday in aftermath of Israeli strike in Doha
items.standfirst: President Trump is expected to meet on Friday evening in New York with Qatar's Prime Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman al-Thani and discuss the aftermath of the Israeli strike against Hamas leaders in Doha earlier this week, two sources with direct knowledge said. Why it matters: The…

items.title: Israel’s Netanyahu says ‘there will be no Palestinian state’
items.standfirst: Israeli prime minister signs agreement to move ahead with expanded settlement plan that would bisect occupied West Bank.
items.content: Israeli prime minister signs agreement to move ahead with expanded settlement plan that would bisect occupied West Bank.

items.title: Netanyahu signs plan to expand West Bank settlement
items.standfirst: Benjamin Netanyahu signed an agreement to expand the illegal Maale Adumim settlement in the occupied West Bank.
items.content: Benjamin Netanyahu signed an agreement to expand the illegal Maale Adumim settlement in the occupied West Bank.

items.title: 'Netanyahu willing to risk his highest diplomatic achievement in order to keep his base'
items.standfirst: FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky reports from Jerusalem as the Israeli strikes on Doha are pushing Qatar to reconsider its role as mediator in the Gaza talks. She says that Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu seems willing to risk his highest diplomatic achievement, the Abraham Accords, in order to keep his base, as he approves a major settlement project in the West Bank and vows that "there will be no Palestinian state".
items.content: FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky reports from Jerusalem as the Israeli strikes on Doha are pushing Qatar to reconsider its role as mediator in the Gaza talks. She says that Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu seems willing to risk his highest diplomatic achievement, the Abraham Accords, in order to keep his base, as he approves a major settlement project in the West Bank and vows that "there will be no Palestinian state".

items.title: Strikes in Qatar: Netanyahu pushes the limits in Israel's war against Hamas
items.standfirst: The unprecedented Israeli strikes against Hamas leaders in Qatar on Tuesday revealed that Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is willing to cross what were previously red lines in his mission to decapitate the Islamist movement. But there may be a high price to pay for such a risky strategy – including for the Israeli hostages still held in Gaza.
items.content: The unprecedented Israeli strikes against Hamas leaders in Qatar on Tuesday revealed that Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is willing to cross what were previously red lines in his mission to decapitate the Islamist movement. But there may be a high price to pay for such a risky strategy – including for the Israeli hostages still held in Gaza.

items.title: Qatar reconsidering its mediator role in Gaza ceasefire talks after Israel strikes Doha
items.standfirst: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu “killed any hope” of releasing hostages still held in the Gaza Strip after Israel attacked Hamas leaders in Doha, Qatar’s prime minister said on Thursday. The comments from Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani underscored the wider anger among Gulf Arab countries over Tuesday's strike that killed at least six people. FRANCE 24's Emerald Maxwell reports.
items.content: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu “killed any hope” of releasing hostages still held in the Gaza Strip after Israel attacked Hamas leaders in Doha, Qatar’s prime minister said on Thursday. The comments from Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani underscored the wider anger among Gulf Arab countries over Tuesday's strike that killed at least six people. FRANCE 24's Emerald Maxwell reports.

items.title: Qatari PM says Israel 'killed any hope' of releasing hostages as criticism over Doha attack intensifies
items.standfirst: Qatar's prime minister said Israel has "killed any hope" of seeing more hostages returned from Gaza after carrying out an attack targeting Hamas leadership in his country.
items.content: Qatar's prime minister said Israel has "killed any hope" of seeing more hostages returned from Gaza after carrying out an attack targeting Hamas leadership in his country.

items.title: Israeli airstrikes ‘killed any hope’ for hostages in Gaza, says Qatari prime minister
items.standfirst: Mohammed bin Abdulrahman bin Jassim al-Thani calls for Benjamin Netanyahu to be ‘brought to justice’Qatar’s prime minister has said that Benjamin Netanyahu “killed any hope” for the remaining hostages in Gaza following Israel’s extraordinary strike on Hamas negotiators in Doha on Tuesday.In an interview with CNN on Wednesday, Mohammed bin Abdulrahman bin Jassim al-Thani called the deadly strike in the Qatari capital an act of “state terror”. Israel’s attack the previous day killed six members of Hamas who were negotiating a ceasefire deal brokered by the US and other Gulf countries. Continue reading...

Israel’s attack the previous day killed six members of Hamas who were negotiating a ceasefire deal brokered by the US and other Gulf countries. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Microsoft, OpenAI reach non-binding deal to allow OpenAI to restructure
clusters.neutral_headline: Microsoft and OpenAI Reach Non-Binding Deal

items.title: Microsoft, OpenAI reach non-binding deal to allow OpenAI to restructure
OpenAI and Microsoft sketch out deal to unlock for-profit restructuring
items.standfirst: Nonbinding term marks progress in talks to enable ChatGPT maker’s eventual IPO
items.content: Nonbinding term marks progress in talks to enable ChatGPT maker’s eventual IPO

items.title: Microsoft and OpenAI reach non-binding deal to allow OpenAI to restructure
OpenAI and Microsoft sign preliminary deal to revise partnership terms
items.standfirst: Companies work to finalize terms as OpenAI pursues for-profit restructuring.
items.content: On Thursday, OpenAI and Microsoft announced they have signed a non-binding agreement to revise their partnership, marking the latest development in a relationship that has grown increasingly complex as both companies compete for customers in the AI market and seek new partnerships for growing infrastructure needs. "Microsoft and OpenAI have signed a non-binding memorandum of understanding (MOU) for the next phase of our partnership," the companies wrote in a joint statement. "We are actively working to finalize contractual terms in a definitive agreement. Together, we remain focused on delivering the best AI tools for everyone, grounded in our shared commitment to safety." The announcement comes as OpenAI seeks to restructure from a nonprofit to a for-profit entity, a transition that requires Microsoft's approval, as the company is OpenAI's largest investor with more than $13 billion committed since 2019.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: Microsoft and OpenAI reached a non-binding deal to allow OpenAI to restructure.
The deal marks progress in talks to enable the ChatGPT maker's eventual IPO.
The companies are working to finalize terms as OpenAI pursues for-profit restructuring.
The agreement involves revising the partnership terms between the two companies.
The deal allows OpenAI to move forward with its plans for restructuring.

items.title: Ghana agrees to accept West Africans deported from the US
items.standfirst: Fourteen West Africans who had been deported from the United States were received in Ghana before being sent on to their home countries. This makes Ghana the fifth African nation to accept US deportees, a decision which has been questioned by lawyers and activists.
